channel.title: Where To Start?
channel.description:
Ok, bought the Java book - Should be coming soon - but I was just thinking about, once I have the basic knowledge of Java, where do I start?
What to I start programming? I was thinking a simple, legal, RuneScape client, but I'm afraid that it might be too advanced for someone who has only just got the basics.
Any ideas/suggestions?
x x

item.title: Where To Start?
item.dc:creator: @iwasinmoparseas101cl iwasinmoparseas101class
item.description:
@iwasinmoparseas101cl wrote:

well then your next step if you feel comfortable with all of that would be to start some GUI work get onto sun’s website documentation:

http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/

and read up on some of their classes, or just check out their src.zip folder in your default installation directory.

Read full topic

item.title: Where To Start?
item.dc:creator: @Mr.Chris Mr.Chris
item.description:
@Mr.Chris wrote:

It’s actually really good. Nearly completed day 1, and learnt quite a bit about Java and the basics of it. Such as classes, methods, superclasses, objects and subclasses.

Read full topic

haha…that is one big ass book. I’d say return it and get a thinner one like Absolute Java or something like that

item.title: Where To Start?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Try some file reading/writing, math operations, and once you have the basics down go for some GUI

Read full topic

item.title: Where To Start?
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

[quote=“Silver Lining, post:3, topic:44971”][quote author=Javacisnotrecognized link=topic=62481.msg744192#msg744192 date=1168135310]
First off, if you are planning on programming an RS client, and you don’t work for Jagex and it isn’t going to be an applet on a page with runescape.com in the URL, then you’re screwed :P.

I would suggest a simple number sorter, or string sorter, or heck even a program that starts an infinite amount of threads that wrecks your computer. Maybe, a program that does nothing but continually throw and catch execeptions, since dealing with exceptions in going to give you the most headaches. (IE not the exceptions themselves, but having to write an annoying as shit try{ }catch(Throwable){} block).
[/quote]Why would programming a client be hard? Just adding a applet to a JFrame to make a basic one… I would suggest just trying to figure out various algorithms until you’ve got a fear of the word “for”[/quote]

[quote=“Mr.Chris, post:1, topic:44971”]Ok, bought the Java book - Should be coming soon - but I was just thinking about, once I have the basic knowledge of Java, where do I start?

What to I start programming? I was thinking a [size=35pt]simple, legal,[/size] RuneScape client, but I’m afraid that it might be too advanced for someone who has only just got the basics.

Any ideas/suggestions?

x x[/quote]

Read full topic

item.title: Where To Start?
item.dc:creator: @Silver_Lining Silver Lining
item.description:
@Silver_Lining wrote:

Mmmk. Stay away from the number sorter though; a better, less painful, course of action would be to puree your arm in a blender.

Read full topic

item.title: Where To Start?
item.dc:creator: @Mr.Chris Mr.Chris
item.description:
@Mr.Chris wrote:

[quote=“Silver Lining, post:3, topic:44971”][quote author=Javacisnotrecognized link=topic=62481.msg744192#msg744192 date=1168135310]
First off, if you are planning on programming an RS client, and you don’t work for Jagex and it isn’t going to be an applet on a page with runescape.com in the URL, then you’re screwed :P.

I would suggest a simple number sorter, or string sorter, or heck even a program that starts an infinite amount of threads that wrecks your computer. Maybe, a program that does nothing but continually throw and catch execeptions, since dealing with exceptions in going to give you the most headaches. (IE not the exceptions themselves, but having to write an annoying as shit try{ }catch(Throwable){} block).
[/quote]Why would programming a client be hard? Just adding a applet to a JFrame to make a basic one… I would suggest just trying to figure out various algorithms until you’ve got a fear of the word “for”[/quote]

Thanks for the help you two.

I’ll take Javac’s advice, and try stuff that isn’t too complex, but will get me used to the language, and then maybe progress on to more experienced, complex things?

Read full topic

item.title: Where To Start?

item.description:

[quote=“Javacisnotrecognized, post:2, topic:44971”]First off, if you are planning on programming an RS client, and you don’t work for Jagex and it isn’t going to be an applet on a page with runescape.com in the URL, then you’re screwed :P.

I would suggest a simple number sorter, or string sorter, or heck even a program that starts an infinite amount of threads that wrecks your computer. Maybe, a program that does nothing but continually throw and catch execeptions, since dealing with exceptions in going to give you the most headaches. (IE not the exceptions themselves, but having to write an annoying as shit try{ }catch(Throwable){} block).[/quote]Why would programming a client be hard? Just adding a applet to a JFrame to make a basic one… I would suggest just trying to figure out various algorithms until you’ve got a fear of the word “for”

Read full topic

item.title: Where To Start?
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

First off, if you are planning on programming an RS client, and you don’t work for Jagex and it isn’t going to be an applet on a page with runescape.com in the URL, then you’re screwed :P.

I would suggest a simple number sorter, or string sorter, or heck even a program that starts an infinite amount of threads that wrecks your computer. Maybe, a program that does nothing but continually throw and catch execeptions, since dealing with exceptions in going to give you the most headaches. (IE not the exceptions themselves, but having to write an annoying as shit try{ }catch(Throwable){} block).
